feed.title: BBC News - Home
feed.subtitle: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
feed.rights: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

entry.title: Gove denies EU vote 'humiliation'
entry.content: Education Secretary Michael Gove tells the BBC the vote on the EU referendum was "not a humiliation" for his leader David Cameron.

entry.title: Oil giant BP at 'turning point'
entry.content: Oil giant BP reports a big rise in third-quarter profits and says it has reached a "turning point" for its operations and production.

entry.title: Gaddafi 'buried in Libya desert'
entry.content: The bodies of former Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi, his son and defence minister were buried in a secret location in the desert at dawn, officials say.

entry.title: Education spending 'falling fast'
entry.content: Public spending on education in the UK is falling at the fastest rate since the 1950s, says the Institute for Fiscal Studies.

entry.title: Turkey quake area to get more aid
entry.content: The Turkish government pledges more aid, as thousands spend a second night in freezing conditions after Sunday's earthquake, which killed at least 366.

entry.title: UBS profit despite trader scandal
entry.content: Swiss bank UBS reports third-quarter net profit of 1bn Swiss francs ($1.1bn; Â£710m), despite being hit by losses from alleged rogue trading.

entry.title: Unions in pension legal challenge
entry.content: The policy of raising public sector pensions in line with the Consumer Prices Index instead of the Retail Prices Index is being challenged.

entry.title: Hillsborough inquiry 'failure'
entry.content: The Blair government "failed very badly" when it accepted the conclusions of Lord Justice Stuart Smith's review of the original Hillsborough inquiry, says former Lord Chancellor Lord Falconer.

entry.title: News Corp suffers investor rebuke
entry.content: About a third of investors voted against the re-election of James and Lachlan Murdoch to the News Corp board, after the UK phone-hacking scandal, it emerges.

entry.title: Tunisian Islamists claim victory
entry.content: Tunisia's moderate Islamist party claims victory in the first free poll of the Arab Spring, but first results suggest it will not have an overall majority.

entry.title: Torrential rain causes flooding
entry.content: Torrential rain hits several parts of the UK and Republic of Ireland, with flooding in south-west England, Northern Ireland and Wales.

entry.title: Policeman killed in m-way smash
entry.content: A policeman is killed in a collision involving a lorry on the M1 near Wakefield after stopping to help a stranded driver.

entry.title: Bee swarm escapes from US lorry
entry.content: A lorry carrying at least 20m bees overturns in the US state of Utah, temporarily closing a highway as its cargo escapes.

entry.title: Campaign against Shakespeare film
entry.content: Pub and road signs in William Shakespeare's home county which bear his name are being temporarily covered as part of a campaign against a new film which questions the authorship of his work.

entry.title: New customers boost Arm Holdings
entry.content: Arm Holdings, the microchip designer whose chips power Apple's iPhones and iPads, sees strong growth in new customers licensing its designs.

entry.title: Job fears 'constrain borrowing'
entry.content: Concerns about jobs and family finances are constraining householders' demand for borrowing, the major banks say.

entry.title: PM defends UK role in euro crisis
entry.content: David Cameron says the UK is prepared to play a "positive role" in helping resolve the eurozone crisis amid reports of a row with the French president.

entry.title: MPs 'not misled' on phone hacking
entry.content: News International's former executive chairman Les Hinton rejects suggestions company executives had been "untruthful" with MPs on phone hacking.

entry.title: Bad eyes 'linked to time indoors'
entry.content: The time children spend outdoors could be one factor which reduces their risk of being short-sighted, research suggests.

entry.title: NHS 'must get ready for genetics'
entry.content: The NHS needs to "urgently" develop the tools and expertise need to take advantage of a revolution in genetic testing, a report says.

entry.title: University applications 'down 9%'
entry.content: Early indications suggest that university applications to the Ucas admissions service for 2012 have declined as higher tuition fees are being introduced.

entry.title: High fees 'deter 10% of students'
entry.content: Higher university fees are putting off one in 10 potential students, a survey commissioned by BBC Inside Out suggests.

entry.title: Wikileaks halts file publishing
entry.content: The whistle-blowing group Wikileaks says it is suspending its publication of classified files due to financial problems.

entry.title: Writer hails 'genius' Steve Jobs
entry.content: The author of a new, official biography of Steve Jobs has spoken about the man he got to know through a series of more than 40 interviews.

entry.title: Javan rhino 'extinct in Vietnam'
entry.content: The critically endangered Javan rhino is now extinct in Vietnam after the last surviving animal was killed, according to a report by conservation groups.

entry.title: Public 'supports geo-engineering'
entry.content: There is strong support among the public in the US, UK and Canada for more research on geo-engineering technology, a study suggests.

entry.title: Murray defence begins arguments
entry.content: Defence lawyers for Conrad Murray, accused in the death of Michael Jackson, begin calling witnesses after four weeks of prosecution testimony.

entry.title: World Book Night titles unveiled
entry.content: Pride and Prejudice and The Alchemist are among the 25 titles that will be given away for World Book Night next year, organisers announce.

entry.title: Evictions, protests, unrest - how Jerusalem saw them coming
entry.content: Jerusalem is back in the West End, but how does the tale about a drug-dealing, drunkard rebel in the English countryside capture today's political mood?

entry.title: Race, class and house parties
entry.content: Racism is rarely a sole cause of social injustice, but alongside other factors it can limit people's social mobility, says Will Self.

entry.title: Police examine Terry allegation
entry.content: Allegations that Chelsea's John Terry racially abused QPR defender Anton Ferdinand are being assessed by the police.

entry.title: Sportsday Live - latest updates
entry.content: Sportsday Live featuring Sven-Goran Eriksson's departure from Leicester, QPR's decision to discuss John Terry's alleged racist slur, England's final one-day international against India, plus more.

entry.title: Live - India v England
entry.content: England face India at Eden Gardens in Kolkata, looking to avoid a 5-0 whitewash, with Kevin Pietersen ruled out because of a fractured thumb but Graeme Swann back in the side.

entry.title: Eriksson departs Leicester role
entry.content: Former England manager Sven-Goran Eriksson leaves his position as Leicester City boss by mutual consent.

entry.title: New Jersey set to host Grand Prix
entry.content: Formula 1 will stage a Grand Prix in New Jersey from 2013, according to West New York mayor Felix Roque.

entry.title: No action over nursery probe pair
entry.content: Two women arrested as part of an investigation into two children's nurseries in York have no further action taken against them.

entry.title: Firework boy's finger blown off
entry.content: A boy loses part of his finger after a firework he is playing with explodes in his hand at a house in Stockport.

entry.title: Peterhead property 'rises most'
entry.content: The fishing town of Peterhead has seen the UK's biggest property price gains over the past decade, according to new figures.

entry.title: Gold mine plan waits on go-ahead
entry.content: Plans to develop Scotland's first commercial gold mine in Loch Lomond National Park could be approved later.

entry.title: 18 are rescued from flood waters
entry.content: Eighteen people are rescued on boats in County Tyrone, as flooding continues to affect many parts of Northern Ireland.

entry.title: Search underway for missing Garda
entry.content: A search is underway for an off-duty Irish police officer who was swept away by flood waters in County Wicklow on Monday evening.

entry.title: Care costs 'forcing house sales'
entry.content: A BBC Wales investigation finds that hundreds of families are selling homes to pay for care home fees, despite a leading lawyer saying they are being wrongly denied NHS funding.

entry.title: Struggle after council farm sales
entry.content: Aspiring farmers are warned that they may struggle to get into the industry as council-owned tenant farms are sold.

entry.title: Libya fuel tank blast 'kills 50'
entry.content: An explosion at a fuel tank has left more than 50 people dead in the Libyan city of Sirte, officials and local residents say.

entry.title: Second blast in Kenya's capital
entry.content: A second blast hits Kenya's capital, Nairobi, killing at least one person at a bus stop, hours after a grenade attack on a bar wounded 12 people.

entry.title: Philippine military bombs rebels
entry.content: Military forces in the Philippines have carried out their first air strikes for three years on Muslim separatist rebels in the south.

entry.title: Thai floods near Bangkok airport
entry.content: Floodwaters are encroaching on areas around Bangkok's domestic airport, as the Thailand continues to battle its worst flooding in five decades.

entry.title: Romania's ex-king to address MPs
entry.content: Romania's former King Michael I is to mark his 90th birthday by addressing parliament in Bucharest for the first time since his abdication in 1947.

entry.title: Mikkelsen awarded for film career
entry.content: Danish actor Mads Mikkelsen, most widely known for his role in Casino Royale, is honoured by the European Film Academy for his screen career.

entry.title: Hurricane Rina forms in Caribbean
entry.content: Hurricane Rina forms in the western Caribbean, threatening to bring heavy rain to southern Mexico and Central America, a region already struggling to recover from deadly floods.

entry.title: Fernandez sweeps to Argentine win
entry.content: Argentine President Cristina Fernandez secures re-election with a landslide victory, polling nearly 54% and far ahead of her nearest rival.

entry.title: Syrians 'tortured' in hospitals
entry.content: Patients in state-run hospitals in Syria are subjected to torture and mistreatment, a report by Amnesty International says, amid continuing unrest.

entry.title: Gaddafi loyalists 'were executed'
entry.content: The bodies of 53 Gaddafi supporters are found outside a hotel in the city of Sirte after apparently being executed, a rights group says.

entry.title: India cuts forecast as rates rise
entry.content: India's central bank raises interest rates and cuts its growth forecast amid high consumer prices and slowing global growth.

entry.title: Foreign travel alerts upset India
entry.content: India criticises alerts issued by five countries asking their citizens to avoid travel to India during the holiday season, warning them of "possible terrorist attacks".

entry.title: US ambassador pulled out of Syria
entry.content: The US pulls out its ambassador to Syria, Robert Ford, because of concerns for his safety, after he angered authorities by visiting activists.

entry.title: Saudi envoy 'plotter' in US court
entry.content: An Iranian-American charged over a plot to assassinate the Saudi ambassador to the US appears in a New York court and pleads not guilty to terror charges.

entry.title: Day in pictures: 24 October 2011
entry.content: 24 hours of news photos: 24 October

entry.title: In pictures: Libya declares liberation
entry.content: Transitional government declares national liberation

entry.title: Week in pictures: 15-21 October 2011
entry.content: Photos from around the world: 15-21 October

entry.title: In pictures: Libya celebrates
entry.content: Reaction to news of Gaddafi's death

entry.title: Day in pictures: 20 October
entry.content: 24 hours of news photos: 20 October

entry.title: In pictures: Anti-Gaddafi forces 'take city of Sirte'
entry.content: Libya's interim authorities claim control

entry.title: In pictures: TB in the Kingdom in the Sky
entry.content: Health workers fight disease

entry.title: In pictures: Wildlife photo award
entry.content: Spiders and a grizzly bears

entry.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
entry.content: Britain's membership of the European Union is "vital for millions of jobs and millions of families", David Cameron has said as he urged MPs to vote against a motion calling for an in or out referendum on Europe.

entry.title: VIDEO: Flash floods hit UK & Ireland
entry.content: Flash flooding has hit parts of south-west England, Northern Ireland and Wales.

entry.title: VIDEO: Queen remembers Australia's war dead
entry.content: The Queen has been greeted with loud cheers by crowds in Canberra where she visited an Australian War Memorial.

entry.title: VIDEO: Cold night for Turkish survivors
entry.content: Rescue teams in Turkey have been working through the night to find more survivors following Sunday's earthquake.

entry.title: VIDEO: 'Epic' Victorian artwork restored
entry.content: Experts at Tate Britain have used the latest technology to restore a work by one of the most popular painters in Victorian England.

entry.title: VIDEO: Jackson trial defence begins case
entry.content: Lawyers defending Michael Jackson's personal physician have called their first witnesses following a four-week case from the prosecution.

entry.title: VIDEO: Moment when quake struck Turkey
entry.content: CCTV cameras have captured the moment when a 7.2 magnitude earthquake struck a region of Turkey.

entry.title: VIDEO: Sicily's volcano Mount Etna erupts
entry.content: Europe's most active volcano Mount Etna has begun to spew large plumes of bright orange lava.

entry.title: VIDEO: England rioters 'poor and young'
entry.content: The most comprehensive statistics published so far on people charged over the August riots in England reveal they were poorer, younger and of lower educational achievement than average.

entry.title: VIDEO: Select Committee
entry.content: Live coverage from the select committee rooms.

entry.title: Eight radical solutions to the housing crisis
entry.content: Eight radical solutions to the UK's housing crisis

entry.title: Agincourt and other great British 'myths'
entry.content: How accurate are our favourite tales from the past?

entry.title: In pictures: Queen visits Australia
entry.content: Images of the Queen's tour of Australia

entry.title: James Murdoch under pressure
entry.content: Robert Peston on whether James Murdoch can still lead BSkyB

entry.title: Switched at birth, then meeting aged 12
entry.content: Pain of a Russian baby mix-up, 12 years on

entry.title: Student, model, nun
entry.content: Why more young women are becoming nuns

entry.title: Brutal murders spark death penalty debate
entry.content: Brutal killings spark execution debate in US

entry.title: Papers assess referendum damage
entry.content: Papers assess referendum vote damage
